creditline: Gift of funds from Nakazawa Noriko in memory of her great-grandfather Fukuda Kodōjin
description: wooden tea caddy that is rectangular in shape, with a round, disk-shaped lid; inscriptions in Japanese characters throughout; rising mountain in black ink on one side of caddy, with small tree at B, in front of mountain; two red stamps on L side of one side of caddy, slightly overlapping with Japanese characters
object_name: Tea caddy, one of a pair
text: In addition to his poetry and painting, from at least 1923 onward Kodōjin joined with various craftsmen in composing poems for and creating decorations on their artworks. Such collaborations were firmly grounded in the literati tradition. They attest to Kodōjin’s versatility, expanding his art practice to attract clients who would not otherwise have been interested in acquiring a painting or a calligraphy.
title: Tea caddy, one of a pair
